property.name: text
property.value: Conway's game of life captures the behavior of a system evolving over generations. On a grid there are Rows*Columns cells (unoccupied ones shown as hollow circles and occupied ones as filled circles). Initially there are InitialOccupants occupied cells randomly located on the grid. The rules to compute the next generation based on the the current occupancy are as follows: 1. If a cell is currently occupied and it has 2 or 3 neighbors (in eight directions), it remains occupied in the next generation. 2. A cell that is not occupied but has exactly 3 neighbors becomes occupied in the next generation. 3. All other cells are unoccupied in the next generation. The grid is toroidal (that is, it wraps around on the four borders). This model uses model transformation to generate an initial grid. It repeatedly computes the next generations with model transformation, until a stable state is reached. Compare to another game of life demo implemented in Ptalon.

property.name: text
property.value: Author: Thomas Huining Feng (Inspired by Adam Cataldo)

property.name: text
property.value: If the JVM runs out of heap space, please execute Java with parameter -Xmx512m.

property.name: actions
property.value: X = X + 1 >= Columns ? 0 : X + 1; Y = X == 0 ? Y + 1 : Y

property.name: Constraint
property.value: (A.x + 1 == B.x || A.x == Columns - 1 && B.x == 0) && A.y == B.y
